head.ce:title: Resolution of the neutron lifetime puzzle and the conceptual design of its experimental confirmation

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The lifetime of free neutrons was a long-standing puzzle: in the beam experiments it significantly exceeded the corresponding result from the trap experiments. The difference far exceeded the experimental error margins. While the results of the trap experiments were based on counting neutrons, the results of the beam experiments were based on counting protons stemming from the three-body decay of a neutron into a free proton and a free electron (plus antineutrino). It was well-known that there is a relatively small probability for the two-body decay of a free neutron into a hydrogen atom (plus antineutrino). For explaining the above puzzle, the Branching Ratio (BR) for this two-body decay – compared to the usual three-body decay – should have been ∼ 1 %. However, the theoretical BR for such two-body decay was previously known to be smaller by several orders of magnitude: 4 × 10–6. In one of our papers of 2024 (hereafter paper I) it was pointed out that after taking into account the second solution of the Dirac equation for hydrogen atoms, the theoretical BR for the two-body decay of free neutrons (into hydrogen atoms and antineutrinos) got enhanced by a factor ∼ 3000 to become ∼ 1 %. Thus, the neutron lifetime puzzle appeared solved completely. In the present paper, the resolution of the neutron lifetime puzzle in this way is just the “stepping stone” leading to the “keystone” (i.e., to the central idea): to the proposed conceptual design of the experiments that will constitute both the first experimental detection of the two-body decay of free neutrons and the experimental confirmation that the two-body decay of free neutrons produces overwhelmingly the hydrogen atoms described by the second solution of the Dirac equation.

ce:section.ce:para: The lifetime of free neutrons was a long-standing puzzle: in the beam experiments (τbeam = 888.0 ± 2.0 s) it significantly exceeded the corresponding result from the trap experiments (τtrap = (877.75 ± 0.28stat + 0.22/−0.16syst) s, (e.g., according to Gonzalez et al. paper [1]). The difference far exceeded the experimental error margins.

While the results of the trap experiments were based on counting neutrons, the results of the beam experiments were based on counting protons – the protons originating from the three-body decay of a neutron into a free proton and a free electron (plus antineutrino). So, if there would be a channel where a neutron decays without producing free protons, this potentially might lead to the resolution of the puzzle.

It was well-known that there is a relatively small probability for the two-body decay of a free neutron into a hydrogen atom (plus antineutrino). For explaining the above puzzle, the Branching Ratio (BR) for this two-body decay – compared to the usual three-body decay – should have been ∼ 1 %. However, the theoretical BR for such two-body decay was previously known to be smaller by several orders of magnitude: 4 × 10–6 – see, e.g., Kabir paper [2] and references therein.

As another possibility, Fornal and Grinstein [3] hypothesized that neutron might decay into some unspecified dark matter (DM) particle. The first immediate problem with their suggestion was that the resulting hypothetical DM particle was not identified. Moreover, Dubbers et al [4] demonstrated that the BR, corresponding to this process, is at least several times lower than the required 1 %. Then in the very recent experiment by Joubioux et al [5], dealing with the hypothetical dark decay 6He → 4He + n + χ, it was shown that from the experimental results follows that the corresponding BR for free neutrons is ∼ 10–5, i.e., by three orders of magnitude smaller than the BR ∼ 1 % required for reconciling τtrap and τbeam.

In paper [6] – hereafter paper I – and in the preceding shorter paper [7]), we pointed out that after taking into account the second solution of the Dirac equation for hydrogen atoms, the theoretical BR for the two-body decay of free neutrons (into hydrogen atoms and antineutrinos) got enhanced by a factor of 3300 to become to 1.3 %. This is in the excellent agreement with “experimental” BR = (1.15 ± 0.27) % needed for explaining the difference between τtrap and τbeam. So, it appears that after allowing for the above, enhanced two-body decay, the neutron lifetime puzzle has been solved completely.

Paper I concentrated on the cosmological outcomes of the above enhanced two-body decay of free neutrons: namely, on neutron stars as producers of the baryonic dark matter in the Universe. That paper was designed for the astrophysical research community: the resolution of the puzzle of the free neutron lifetime was just the premise.

In distinction, the present paper is intended for the research community dealing with the nuclear and particle physics. So, here the resolution of the neutron lifetime puzzle in this way is just the “stepping stone” leading to the “keystone” (i.e., to the central idea): to the proposed conceptual design of the experiment that will constitute both the first experimental detection of the two-body decay of free neutrons and the experimental confirmation that the two-body decay of free neutrons produces overwhelmingly the hydrogen atoms described by the second solution of the Dirac equation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Brief overview of the background: How the second solution of the Dirac equation for hydrogen atoms became legitimate
ce:section.ce:para: There are two analytical solutions of the standard Dirac equation of quantum mechanics for hydrogen atoms: 1) the solution that is weakly singular at small r; 2) the solution that is more strongly singular at small r. The radial part of the coordinate wave functions for the ground state has the following scaling at small r:(1)R0,−1(r)∝1/rq,q=1±(1−α2)1/2.

Here α is the fine structure constant; – 1 in the subscript of the wave function R0,–1 is the eigenvalue of the operator K = β(2Ls +1) that commutes with the Hamiltonian; β is the Dirac matrix of the rank 4; s and L are the spin and orbital angular momenta operators, respectively.

Thus, the first solution is characterized by only a weak singularity: q ≈ α2/2 ≈ 0.000027 (hereafter, the “regular” solution, for brevity). The second solution is significantly singular (q ≈ 2) and it is usually rejected, the reason being the divergence of the normalization integral at r = 0.

However, the allowance for the finite nuclear size changes the situation. In paper [8] we obtained a general class of potentials inside the nucleus, such that the singular solution outside the nucleus can be in fact matched with the corresponding regular solution inside the nucleus at the boundary. Specifically, in that paper there was considered an arbitrary spherically-symmetric interaction potential V(r), having two different shapes in the interior region r 〈 R and in the exterior region r 〉 R. It was demonstrated that the singular solution in the exterior region can be matched at the boundary with the regular solution at the interior region for the class of potentials satisfying the following condition (written in the natural units ħ = me = c = 1)(2)∫0RV(r′)r′2dr+(1−E)r3/3≈{∫R∞[V(r′)/r′2]dr′−(1+E)/r}−1.
In Eq. (2), E is the total energy of the atomic electron, including the rest energy.

Potentials in the interior region satisfying Eq. (2) should rapidly rise toward the boundary r = R. Charge Density Distributions (CDDs) that have the maximum at r = 0 and falls off to the periphery yield one particular case of such potentials.

The CDD inside protons does have the maximum at r = 0 and falls off to the periphery. This is well-known since 1980s from the experiment on the elastic scattering of electrons on protons – see, e.g., works by Simon et al [9] and Perkins [10]. So, the singular solution of the Dirac equation outside the proton can be matched with the regular solution of the Dirac equation inside the proton at the boundary.

The derivation of the corresponding wave function in paper [8] utilized only the fact that the eigenvalue of the operator K in the ground state is k = –1. Therefore, in fact, the corresponding derivation is valid for all states of hydrogen atoms having the quantum number k = –1.

Such states are the S-states: the states where the orbital angular momentum l is equal to zero. Thus, both the singular and regular solution of the Dirac equation outside the proton are permissible for all S-states, as well as for the states of the continuous spectrum having l = 0 [11].

This second type of hydrogen atoms that have only the S-states was later named the Second Flavor of Hydrogen Atoms, hereafter SFHA [12]. The reason is explained in Appendix A of the present paper. The existence of the SFHA has been evidenced by four different kinds of atomic experiments and by an astrophysical observation – details are also provided in the Appendix A of the present paper.

It is important to underscore that the theory of the SFHA is based on the standard quantum mechanics (the Dirac equation). It does not require going beyond the Standard Model of particle physics and it does not recourse to changing the physical laws.

The SFHA does not couple to the electromagnetic radiation – due to the selection rules for the S-states. Namely, all matrix elements (both diagonal and non-diagonal) of the radius-vector r of the atomic electron are zeros. Therefore, there is no coupling to the dipole or any higher multipole radiation and no multi-photon transitions.
However, the SFHA can be excited or ionized by the electron impact. This is because for such 3-body problem, the selection rules differ from the 2-body problem referred to in the previous paragraph.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Overview of the resolution of the neutron lifetime puzzle
ce:section.ce:para: In paper I, there was demonstrated the following. For the two-body decay of a free neutron into hydrogen atom plus antineutrino, its probability Pns is proportional to the square absolute value of the electron wave function at the nuclear surface R (see, e.g., Bahcall paper [13]):(3)Pns=const|Ψns(R)|2.

In Eq. (3), Ψns(R) is the value of the atomic electron wave function at r = R (“const” is the normalization constant whose specific value is immaterial for obtaining the ratio of probabilities below). We concentrate on the formation of hydrogen atoms in the ground state 1S because there is an overwhelming probability that, as a result of the neutron two-body decay, hydrogen atoms will be in 1S state rather than in any higher S-state:(4)P1s=const|Ψ1s(R)|2.

So, we calculated the following Enhancement Factor (EF)(5)EF(R)=P2(R)/P1(R)=[g2(R)2+f2(R)2]/[g1(R)2+f1(R)2],where g1(R) and f1(R) are the bispinor components of the well-known regular solutions of the Dirac equation for hydrogen atoms (see, e.g., the textbook [14]), while g2(R) and f2(R) are the bispinor components of the second solutions of the Dirac equation. Outside the proton, in its immediate vicinity:(6)g2(r)=C/r2,f2(r)=−2Cα/r2,where C is the normalization constant. On substituting in Eq. (5) as the proton boundary R, the experimental root-mean-square value of the proton radius 0.85 fm = 0.0022 n.u., we obtain EF ∼ 3 × 103 >> 1. This means that the two-body decay of a free neutron is – with the overwhelming probability – the SFHA rather than the usual hydrogen atom. Physically, this is because the second solution wave function increases toward the proton much more rapidly than the first solution wave function.

Thus, the theoretical BR, after being enhanced by a factor of ∼ 3000, reaches ∼ 1 %. This is in the excellent agreement with “experimental” BR = (1.15 ± 0.27) % needed for explaining the difference between the above values of τtrap and τbeam. So, it appears indeed that the above, drastically enhanced probability of the two-body decay of neutrons resolves the neutron lifetime puzzle completely.
There are also important cosmological consequences of the above results. A brief overview of these consequences is given in Appendix B.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conceptual design of its experimental confirmation
ce:section.ce:para: The starting point can be the design created by McAndrew et al [15] – see Fig. 1.

There is the through-going beam tube where the neutrons decay. Next is the collimator through which the hydrogen toms pass. (The Lamb-shift spin filter is not necessary for our purpose.) Then most of the three-body decay protons and electrons is removed by the transverse magnetic field B3.

The crux of our proposal is the following. After passing the magnetic field B3, the hydrogen atoms should be acted upon by an electric field (a static field or a laser field) able to ionize the usual hydrogen atoms from the states 2S, 3S, and so on. The SFHA cannot and will not be ionized by this field, as mentioned above in Section 2.

As a result of the 2-body decay of neutrons, it is theoretically expected that 83.2 % of the resulting hydrogen atoms will be in the state 1 s and 16.8 % of the resulting hydrogen atoms will be in the states 2 s, 3 s, and so on [13]. In the 1st mode of the experiment, the ionizing laser or static electric field should not be engaged. Then all hydrogen atoms should be acted upon by an electron beam of the energy ∼ (6 – 8) eV to ionize both kinds of hydrogen atoms from the state 2S and higher. (We remind that the SFHA can be ionized by the electron beam.) Then, by applying a static electric field, the resulting protons should be deflected and counted.

In the 2nd mode of the experiment, one should engage the ionizing laser or static electric field. Then, as in the 1st mode, all hydrogen atoms should acted upon by an electron beam of the energy ∼ (6 – 8) eV to ionize both kinds of hydrogen atoms from the state 2S and higher. Thereafter, the resulting protons should be deflected and counted. If the 2nd count of protons would be just about the same as the 1st count, this would manifest that the 2-body decay of neutrons produces overwhelmingly the SFHA (rather than the usual hydrogen atoms). If the 2nd count of protons turned out to be much less than the 1st count, this would mean the absence of the SFHA.
An alternative starting point can be the design of the beam-type experiment by Nico et al [16] – see Fig. 2.

The trapping region in this experiment intercepts the whole neutron beam and neutrons decay inside the trapping region in the 3-body and 2-body ways. In the mode called “trapping” in paper [16], the protons yielded by the 3-body decay of neutrons are confined there. Then, in the mode called “counting” in paper [16], the door electrodes are grounded, and a graduated potential is applied to the central electrodes, so that protons get flushed out..

Here is the crux of our proposal. The hydrogen atoms, yielded by the 2-body decay of neutrons, should be acted upon by an electron beam of the energy 11 – 13 eV to excite both kinds of hydrogen atoms into the states of the principal quantum number n = 2 and higher. Then, in the 1st mode of the experiment, the hydrogen atoms should be acted upon by another electron beam of the energy ∼ (6 – 8) eV to ionize both kinds of hydrogen atoms from the state 2S and higher. Thereafter, the resulting protons should be counted.

In the 2nd mode of the experiment, first the usual hydrogen atoms in the state 2S and higher should be quenched out by an electric field. Namely, the electric field will intermix the S- and P-states, causing the radiative decay into the ground state. (The SFHA cannot be quenched: there are no P-states in the SFHA.) Thereafter, the SFHA in the state 2S and higher, should be acted upon by the second electron beam of the energy ∼ (6 – 8) eV to ionize them. Then the resulting protons should be counted.

If the 2nd count of protons would be just about the same as the 1st count, this would manifest that the 2-body decay of neutrons produces overwhelmingly the SFHA (rather than the usual hydrogen atoms). If the 2nd count of protons turned out to be much less than the 1st count, this would mean the absence of the SFHA.

In paper I, it was demonstrated theoretically that the two-body decay of free neutrons should produce overwhelmingly the SFHA – not the usual hydrogen atoms. As a result, the theoretical BR for the two-body decay compared to the three-body decay got drastically increased to become about 1 % – in the excellent agreement with BR required for the complete resolution of the free neutron lifetime puzzle.

This complete resolution of the long-standing puzzle of the neutron lifetime has also important cosmological consequences. In paper I, it was also shown that neutron stars, through the two-body decay of free neutrons, can generate new baryonic dark master in the form on the “dark” hydrogen atoms (i.e., in the form of the SFHA) and that there is some astrophysical evidence of this process.

Based on the results from paper I, in the current paper we presented the conceptual design of the experiments that will constitute both the first experimental detection of the two-body decay of neutrons and the experimental confirmation that the two-body decay of neutrons produces overwhelmingly the SFHA. We presented all details of the proposed experiment with two possible experimental designs.

The free neutron lifetime is an important parameter in the Standard Model (because it is employed as an input for calculating the quark mixing matrix) and also because it controls the time scale for the nucleosynthesis to occur in the early Universe. Therefore, we believe that our results are of fundamental significance and, most importantly, will stimulate experimental groups to perform the proposed breakthrough experiments.
This research did not receive any funding.

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:section-title: Brief overview of laboratory and astrophysical evidences of the existence of the SFHA
ce:section.ce:para: There was a huge, multi-order discrepancy between the experimental and theoretical distributions of the linear momentum in the ground state of hydrogen atoms. The attention to this huge discrepancy, illustrated in Fig. A.1, was brought in paper [8].Fig. A.1Ratio of the theoretical High-energy Tail of the linear Momentum Distribution (HTMD) in the ground state of hydrogen atoms, calculated in paper [17], to the actual HTMD deduced in paper [18] from the analysis of atomic experiments. The linear momentum p is in units of mc, where m is the electron mass and c is the speed of light. Reproduced from book [19]. Copyright Oks, 2022.Fig A1

From Fig. A.1 one can see that there was up to 4 orders of magnitude discrepancy between the experimental and previous theoretical results in the relevant range of the linear momentum p: mee2/ħ < p << mec. The experimental HTMD falls off much-much slower than the theoretical one.

After the allowance for the presence of the SFHA, this huge multi-order discrepancy got completely removed, as shown in paper [8]. The reason is the following. For the singular solution of the standard Dirac equation outside the proton, a much stronger rise of the coordinate wave function toward the proton at small r translates into a much slower decline of the wave function in the momentum-representation for large p – in accordance with the properties of the Fourier transform, by which the coordinate and momentum wave functions are interrelated. The removal of this huge multi-order discrepancy between the theoretical and experimental results represented the first experimental evidence of the existence of the SFHA – since any alternative explanation for this huge discrepancy was never given.

By now then existence of the SFHA is evidenced also by three other kinds of atomic experiments:-
from electron impact excitation of hydrogen atoms-
from electron impact excitation of hydrogen molecules-
from charge exchange between low energy protons and hydrogen atoms.

For all of them, the SFHA-based explanation removed large discrepancies (up to a factor of two or more) between the experimental and previous theoretical results, while alternative explanations were never given. (The corresponding experimental and previous theoretical results were published in papers [20–26]; the SFHA-based explanations of the discrepancies were published in papers [27–29].)

Besides, there is also an evidence of the existence of the SFHA from the baffling observation by Bowman et al [30] of the anomalous absorption in the (redshifted) 21 cm line from the early Universe. The absorption signal was observed to be about twice stronger than predicted by the standard cosmology. This meant that the temperature of the primordial hydrogen gas was significantly smaller than expected from the standard cosmology.

Barkana [31] hypothesized that some unspecified DM particles provided an additional cooling of the hydrogen gas by collisions. The quantitative explanation required that unspecified DM particles to have the mass of the order of baryon masses. In other words, his explanation needed unspecified baryonic DM particles. Later McGaugh [32] concurred with his conclusion.

Then in paper [11] the author analyzed the situation where the above unspecified baryonic dark matter particles would be the SFHA. The most important property of the SFHA is the following. In virtue of the SFHA having only the S-states and in view of the well-known selection rules of quantum mechanics, the SFHA do not couple to the electromagnetic radiation – they remain dark (the exception being the 21 cm spectral line corresponding to the radiative transition between the hyperfine sublevels of the ground state). So, in paper [11] it was explicated that as the Universe expanded, the SFHA, due to having only the S-states, decoupled from the cosmic microwave background radiation earlier than the usual hydrogen atoms. Therefore, their spin temperature was significantly lower than for the usual hydrogen atoms (the spin temperature controls the absorption signal in the 21 cm spectral line). In this way, the “abnormal” absorption observed by Bowman et al [30] was explained in paper [11] both qualitatively and quantitatively, and made the SFHA a compelling candidate for the baryonic DM – within the Standard Model of particle physics (since being based on the standard Dirac equation) and without changing the physical laws – in contrast to most theories of DM.

Of course, this leaves a playground for other candidates for the baryonic DM, such as, e.g., heavy dark atoms suggested in Beylin et al paper [33] introducing a new hypothetical heavy particle X−2n (so far there is no experimental or observational evidence of the existence of such particle). Even a greater space is still left for investigating nonbaryonic DM, whose ratio to the baryonic dark matter is about 5 to 1, as it is known from the observational results released by the Plank Collaboration – see, e.g., Arbey and Mahmoudy review [34].
For further details we refer to review [35] on DM. In that review the author wrote, in particular the following.

“It is well possible that the effects assigned to dark matter in different types of astrophysical observations do not have one universal cause, i.e., one universal type of “dark matter” … None of the existing theories has to explain each and every astrophysical observation because dark matter could be a multi-faceted phenomenon.”
Finally, here is the reason why hydrogen atoms having only the S-states are called the Second Flavor of Hydrogen Atoms (SFHA) – we quote from review [35].

“For hydrogen atoms, both the regular and singular solutions of the Dirac equation outside the proton correspond to the same energy. Since this means the additional degeneracy, then according to the fundamental theorem of quantum mechanics, there should be an additional conserved quantity. In other words: hydrogen atoms have two flavors, differing by the eigenvalue of this additional, new conserved quantity: hydrogen atoms have flavor symmetry … It is called so by analogy with quarks that have flavors.”

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix B
ce:section.ce:para: Due to the above results, neutron stars can be considered as the producers of the baryonic DM in the Universe, as presented in paper I. There are three pertinent situations, as follows.

First, old neutron stars (of ages of the order of or greater than 107 years) undergo neutrons decay at the star surface, the decay products being released into the atmosphere of the stars. Via the two-body decay channel of the BR ∼ 1 %, neutrons produce the SFHA (plus antineutrinos). Because the temperature is of the order of or smaller than 1 eV (see, e.g., Gonzalez and Reisenegger paper [36]), the produced SFHA continue to exist and slowly accrue in the atmospheres of these stars.

Second, neutron stars, whose mass becomes somewhat smaller than of the order of 0.1 of the solar mass, undergo the hydrodynamic destruction in the explosive way [37]. Neutrons get thrown into the interstellar medium. There neutrons decay through the three-body and two-body processes. In the neutral or ionized interstellar medium, as well as in the H II regions, where the temperature is of the order of or <1 eV, the produced SFHA continue to exist and slowly accrue.
Third, in the process of mergers of a neutron star with a black hole or with another neuron star, a neutron-rich material gets ejected [38–40]. As the ejecta cools down, the SFHA can form.

Thus, in all the three ways described above, neutron stars can slowly generate new specific, described in detail baryonic DM in the form of the SFHA. There is an observational evidence of this, as explained in paper I.
